title: CROWDMAP: Crowdsourcing Ontology Alignment with Microtasks

author: Cristina Sarasua, Institute for Web Science and Technologies (WeST), University of Koblenz-Landau

segmentation: Hi everybody, I am Christina Sosua and this talk.
It's about crowdsourcing the task of ontology alignment through microtask and this is a joint work together with Elena.
Simple annotations.
So.
So our motivation is in the context of Link data interlinks are.
Crucial for data integration an when we think about this links or interlinks we can think about the schema level or the data level.
So we can think about the equivalent relationship but also some assumption or same as relationships or even domain specific relationships.
But this talk is about ontology alignment and we concentrate on this schema level then.

If we look at the literature, we see that there are many data sources that have proprietary vocabularies, but these vocabularies are not mapped to other vocabularies that are more the most popular or the most used ones.
So ontology mapping it.

Still a problem to solve or just to populate on the elody cloud, but there is a lot of work done in ontology alignment in the last decade and we have plenty of tools that are very useful but are shown in the ontology Alignment Evaluation Initiative.
They don't perform, ideally or not all of them, so automatic techniques have problems in discovering so mappings and some of the discovered mappings are not really correct.
So we can think, for example, about two concepts conference on Congress and how should an automatic tool realized that this is.
These are equivalent classes if they have very different attributes, for example.
So we thought, how can we use human intervention to improve the situation?
So.

Our goal is to use crowdsourcing in ontology alignment, which means outsourcing the problem of ontology alignment to the crowd, and when I say the crowd the crowd, I mean everyone in the world who wants to contribute.
So the main idea is to extend current technology.
We don't want to just replace the role of prompt or any other tool, we just want to include human computation in these parts where it is needed.

The idea is also to create alignment micro tasks which are very simple tasks that can be done in parallel independently by many users, and we know that in human computation there are many other alternatives, like for example volunteering or games with a purpose, but we decided to use the incentive of payment or money so that workers that contribute to our micro tasks get paid.
And these microtasks are in the end published in our so called Labor marketplace.
For this is an example.
Is Amazon mturk.
So the people that are interested in these stages go to M Turk, which is an online platform.
They register their, they browse different types of micro tasks an if they get interested in our micro task data.
Work on them and they get money back and M Turk is a very generic platform where requesters that is the people who want to create this micro task can do almost anything.
So the challenge is to do it in an appropriate way so that you don't get many spammers contributing to your micro task.
Or at least if you get them you are able to identify them and to configure everything so that you can get good results.
The scenario that we would like to cover with our work is the following.
So we have Henry, the ontology engineer who wants to align to ontology.
So he uses his favorite tool which can be prompt or any other and he runs it and gets a set of mappings.
But he knows that he should go through the results.
So instead of doing it himself he just uses the crowd map extension and then crowd map gets these set of mappings.

So called candidate mappings and builds automatically microtasks and this microtask are published at M Turk, so the crowd will see something like this small sketch that shows that the workers are ask something like do you think that there is a relationship between conference and Congress?
They get also some contextual information to understand the context better and then they have a form where they can fulfill the the.
What they think is the answer, and once the crowd is has replied to everything, then crowdmark collects all this information.
So mainly the research questions that we were investigating where whether ontology alignment is really amenable for microtask crowdsourcing an how does this approach compared to automatic tools?
We have a joint.
Conversation here.

So going going into more detail into the crowd map workflow, the automatic Ontology alignment tool gets two as input two ontologies and when it's run it just generates a set of candidate mappings and then crowd map gets this as an input and with the configuration that it's needed, it gives us our result a set of verified mappings and crowd map is able to generate 2.
Types of of microtasks validation microtask an identification microtasks so that workers can see something like.
This concept is equivalent to this concept, and they can say yes or no, or they can identify their relationship between two concepts.

Unselecting it from from a list an, we did crowd map so that we can ask for many workers to contribute in our micro tasks, but we would like to we want to guarantee that at least two of them agree on the on the answer.
So what we do is if we have a forum with two options, because we are asking about the the equivalent property, we are asking for three workers to work on our micro task.
And in the case of having four options, then we ask for seven and like this, we guarantee that at least we have two people saying something, I mean agreeing.
The crowd.

Architecture is this one and mainly we have an ontology engineer who will provide the ontologies in the automatic tool and this is what crowd map gets an the crowd will only interact on in M Turk and in between.
We have Crowdflower because we are not directly working with M Turk in between we use Crowd Flower because it's on another microtask platform.
But it is very useful because we can publish the same microtask in different labor market places at the same time.
And also Crowdflower provides very useful quality control features that makes it easier to get good answers from the people.
So mainly we have different components and some of them are for creating the micro tasks and others are just for reading their result of the crowd.
So the first component is.
For building the set of mappings and for this we are parsing the result or the mappings that aren't automatic tool is generating.
But we can also generate these mappings with a set of benchmark methods that we implemented.

Then there is a microtask generator which is the one responsible for creating the real interface of the microtask and then a publisher through these to crowd flower and cloud flower is the one who publishes this.
On M Turk and once the crowd has completed the jobs, then we have a reader for saving this information locally and we have also wrestled professor that.
Simply generates the crowd alignment in RDF XML file and we also have an evaluator that uses the Alignment API for comparing the crowd alignment against the reference alignment.
In case we have it.
This is how the user interface looks like and what we do is show first kind of problem statement and then we have a form.
So in the problem statement we show the two concepts that we want to align or that we are trying to map with the crowd and we show the label.
But we also show in contextual information and this is mainly the definition.
The siblings of the concept, the superclasses, the subclasses an.
In case the ontology has its own.
Instances also to show examples and then in the form we have first.
The main question where we ask about their relationship, and as I said in case it's a validation microtask we ask directly, is concept A the same as concept be yes or no?
And in the case of identification Micro.
Ask we show a list of relationships that can fit between the two concepts.
Then after the main question what we also have is a couple of verification questions so that we apply the workers to work a bit more.
So this is just a way to identify easy, more easily the spammers.
Because there are people that simply go to M Turk and because they want to earn some dollars they simply click on the first thing they see in the in the form and they don't read it.
But like this.
Asking what are you seeing in concept A or how many words do you see in concept a week and we can see who is doing this.

So we set up crowd Flower and M Turk using templates and fulfill this templates with the real mappings because this is how it's done in crowd, flower and the important feature of crowd flower that we used are the Golden the Golden units.
So Crowdflower allows you to create Golden units and to provide the answer for these units, and they're mainly very easy.
Units that also work as training set for the workers so they really learn with them.
So we just define a set of very easy 50 Golden mapping units.
Just simple mappings.
Unlike this crowd flower was able to determine the accuracy of the workers and each of the microtask contained six real mappings on one of these Golden mappings and we were paying 1 cent.
For each of these microtasks, and in the case of Cartesian product, we raise this to four cents because we wanted things to be done quickly.
But of course we got also more spam and we also said the so called property after goal to two, which means we told Crowdflower to only define a work worker, trusted when he or she replies to.
2 Golden units properly.
So by default everyone is considered as an interested worker, but once you get 2 Golden units done correctly, then you become trusted and your.
Are your responses will be taken into account into their result?

We also organized microtasks or the hits that are called like this in M Turk in groups or batches of at maximum 50 and we did it in a way that half of them were had the user interface that I was showing, but the other half had the form had the.
So the options just in the opposite order and we were asking in the verification questions about the other concept, just to make it more difficult.
For the spammers.
So we did our evaluation with the ontology Alignment Evaluation Initiative data, and we got the ontologies and their reference alignments for the conference and they oriented matching ontologies.
So we did several experiments, building the set of mappings differently.
With these three methods.
So the first method was used using the Cartesian product, so we took all the classes of 1 ontology and all the classes of the other ontology, and we build all the possibilities an.
We through this to the crowd.

The second method was to get the the result that they are Roma algorithm produced and for this we didn't really create mappings and put them on the M Turk because we simulated this by just selecting their relevant resource in the Cartesian product.
And the third method method that we used was.

So we call it the 100 recall and 50 precision because this is what we are simulating because we get the reference alignment and we get all the correct mappings and the same number of incorrect mappings.
And this is what the crowd is looking through.
So these are the results an in each column we can see the method that we used on the ontologies of the alignment.

So what I would like to highlight here is that the in the Cartesian product and the implementation method we got very high recall on in the other method, the thing that was the best was the precision.
So if we compare these to the data.
It was provided by the initiative.

We saw that our crowd mob algorithm was performing quite good compared to the to the other tools, and in the case of the Roma algorithm, we run the tool and we were able to improve precision and recall.
Was not I mean it was it was perfect, so it cannot be improved.

So in the end we got an average number of 11 users per group of micro tasks, and the agreement computed by Crowdflower was approximately 87%, and this was taken from a sample of 100 random units and just compute it by looking at how many users were agreeing on this.
And we spend in total, $50, including the several pilots that we were running before the final experiments and the set of mappings had sizes of in the case of the Cartesian product 600 mappings.
But in other cases where 40 or 20 more or less.
So going back to the research questions, we see that it is amenable.
It is feasible to use crowdsourcing for ontology alignment.
Looking at the Cartesian product because there we did it draw rolly and and it worked.
An if we look at the improvement compared to the automatic tools, we see that we can improve precision, losing their recall, which is a good.
A good thing, and we also realized that we could build a two step crowd map algorithm mixing the approach of the implementation of the implemented method.
So taking the result of the, for example Aroma algorithm but also running afterwards.
This set of 100 recall andfifty precision mapping so that we could get more or less ideal precision and recall mixing these two approaches.

For the different pilots we were trying different wording because we realized that for example in the first question when we ask instead of concept a an concept B are the same if we ask about the two concepts, we are equivalent.
The workers didn't perform as well as with asking whether they are the same we in the data we still implement.
The the relationship is an equivalent class relationship, but for the workers is apparently.
Easier to recognize the equivalence relationship when we just say it as same and also in the case of.

Verification questions were instead of showing the two concepts and when we said just select the name you are seeing in concept A, the workers were simply writing a so we just tried with different options in the user interface and we decided to just show the two the two concepts with radio buttons.
And we really saw that the Golden units were Hill helping because in the beginning we didn't use this feature of Crowdflower, and we got almost immediate results.
But there the precision under recall that we got was a disaster.
And this means that we had a lot of spammers and we also show that the crowd identified missing valid mappings, which is we got.
As a result, some mappings that in our opinion were correct because they were matching things like person and person.
But in the reference alignment it was, it was not there.
So what I mean with this is that our evaluation depends also directly on the reference alignments that we were using.

And we realized that crowd flower is really an alternative to using directly M Turk because we see that in the related work everyone, or at least it's more common to see that people are using directly entered.
But Crowdflower really helps in controlling the spammers.
So.
Our future work or even ongoing work is to look at which is the most useful information.
In in the contextual information, so is the definition.
The thing that really gives the clue to the workers to replied correctly or is the is the information about the siblings or their superclasses or the Super properties?
Because we try this first with classes.
But now we are also trying with properties and we are also trying to look at.
Ontologies that require specific domain knowledge, such As for example, the be ontologies we're trying to build qualification tests that make.
Crowdflower just reject or allow someone to work on the microtask.

Depending on their results they get in this qualification test and we are trying to build them just by creating a test using the different concepts that appear in the ontologies so that they can show whether they are experts in the domain or not.
An another step is to look at the extension of their approach to data interlinking, so with instances.

So as a conclusion, crowdsourcing techniques allow to obtain human contributions in a very easy and cheap way, but good results really require an appropriate management of the both microtask on workers, and particularly since we are dealing with workers that are non semantic web experts also.
And crossers ontology alignment.
That is, the our approach with crowd map seems to be feasible.
And apparently we could improve precision and recall of current automatic techniques.
So thank you very much and if there is any question.
